author: AlanBill
body:
This was actually closer to 9 or 10 on my list (my list was not in order). It’s P/E is a little high, but it’s got some positives I couldn’t ignore.

1. It’s P/S (important metric for a growth stock) and P/B are decent still.

2. Starboard (investment company) has a history of producing good returns for shareholders based on their previous investments.

3. The coming auto revolution cannot be ignored. ON has some serious long-term autonomous driving plays.

4. They’ve been growing through acquisitions since their inception and with a new CEO at the helm, I think they’re poised for growth from within.

Also, you reminded me... Disclosure: I am long ON and AMAT.

author: snyder810
body:
IRTC - digital heart monitoring, their product will become the preferred method and continue to gain market share.

EXAS - cologuard is an incredible base for growth, not an outrageous sales multiple for the yoy numbers in 2020

HII - I love this investment, monopoly for their US defense market, but this is a safer 15-25% growth story which will likely bore most.

COTY - riskier play because it’s betting on a rebound, but I like their new CEO and the upside of the risk/reward in what they’re doing.

AMAT & LRCX - probably going to cool to correct for a bit, but the growth story for semiconductor manufacturers needing to expand capacity hasn’t changed, they keep benefitting.

I also like the more talked about - SQ (I’ve alternated bullish, to bearish, and back in), TDOC, V, & MA a lot.

author: RogueJello
body:
I think it depends on the company, and how important innovation really is to the industry.  For Pepsi, having people in sales and marketing running things makes a lot of sense.  Same for P&G.  Not so good at a tech company, where you expect a much higher rate of change.  I'd argue your generalization is broad enough to not be useful.

I have heard a lot of arguments for 'product people', but at the CEO level I don't believe it matters.  Most of the decisions the CEO is going to be making are going to be allocation of capital, managing people, and representing the company to the outside world.  They are not getting down into the really hard technical problems, for that it's going to be the ground level engineers and the middle managers.  The comments about Intel's culture should be more concerning than who their CEO is.

While it's possible for an engineer to make a good CEO, it's a very different skill set from designing chips or other highly technical problems.

Further your comments are very ageist.  I understand it's definitely a thing for older people to not be up on the latest goings on, there are CEO's Swan's age running successful semi conductor companies.  Gary Dickerson (64) of Applied Materials (also not an Engineer), Rich Templeton of Texas Instruments (61), Andy Grove was 62 when he stepped down due to health issues, Gordon Moore was CEO of Intel at 58, Sherman Fairchild was 61 when he founded Fairchild Semiconductor from which Intel drew it's founders.

author: Lostrod
body:
I understand your logic. As someone who works in the industry Intel has a huge PhD based culture, sort of like IBM, which makes it very difficult for them to pivot in any sort of meaningful way in my opinion.

If MSFT and others continue to accelerate learning with TSMC, you might see Intel with no growth the next couple years. If you are in your 20s I think you can take more risk. If you want to play semiconductors look at companies like AMAT or ASML which sell equipment Intel would use.

author: Dasky34
body:
IBM doesn't care because their profits aren't made from fanboys building servers in their basement with dreams of hosting websites. They make the $$$ from Gov't / old business contracts that react slower than dirt to changing times. Sure it'll upset a few people but tech companies don't care about IBM CentOs cause they've pimped their own linux systems already.

Bottom line IBM is gonna split, some old money will make $$, both companies will be slightly fancier version of HPE / HPQ to regular boomer investors that fancy average returns.

author: dwdsquared2
body:
**Events in the US Today (ET):**

* DAY - Wear a mask & socially distance <3
* 8:55am - Redbook (MoM&YoY) \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 9:45am - Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:00am - ISM Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Fed Chair Powell & Steven Mnuchin Testimony continues \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * ISM Manufacturing Employment (Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 12:00pm - FOMC Member Brainard Speaks \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 1:00pm - 52-Week Bill Auction \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 1:15pm - FOMC Member Daly Speaks \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 4:30pm - API Weekly Crude Oil Stock \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 7:00pm - Total Vehicle Sales \[1/3 Volatility\]
* Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is expected to caution lawmakers that the U.S. economy remains in a damaged and uncertain state.
* Tesla’s shares popped 4% in premarket trading after S&P Dow Jones Indices said the electric-car maker will be added to the S&P 500 on Dec. 21 in a single step despite its large size. The index provider had considered adding the $500 billion stock in multiple phases.

**Events in the World Today (ET):**

* 2:00am - UK Nationwide HPI (MoM&YoY-Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 3:15am - Spain Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 3:45am - Italy Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 3:50am - France Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 3:55am - Germany Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Germany Unemployment Change (Nov) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 4:00am - Euro Zone Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 4:30am - UK Manufacturing PMI (Nov) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 5:00am - Euro Zone CPI (YoY-Nov) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * OPEC Meeting \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 8:30am - Canada GPD (MoM-Sep) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 9:30am - New Zealand GlobalDairyTrade Price Index \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 12:00pm - Euro Zone ECB President Lagarde Speaks \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 4:30pm - Australia AIG Manufacturing Index \[2/3 Volatility\]
   * Australia Building Consents (MoM) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 7:30pm - Australia GDP (QoQ-Q3) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* Cyclical shares led the Stoxx Europe 600 Index higher as banks, miners and energy firms climbed. U.K. stocks were up almost 2% after Goldman Sachs Group Inc. strategists called them a buy ahead of a Brexit trade deal.
* Pfizer Inc. and partner BioNTech SE have sought regulatory clearance for their Covid-19 vaccine in the European Union and BioNTech said it could start shipping the first doses “within hours” after approval.
* Oil erased earlier losses as OPEC+ sought more time to reach a deal on production policy.

**Earnings Before Open:**

* Momo, Scotiabank, BMO, Golub Capital

**Earnings After Close:**

* Salesforce, At Home, Box, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Veeva, NetApp, Trip.com

[Earnings This Week](https://i.imgur.com/ShSvr9G.png)

author: diamondtype
body: HPE is a good long play right now. I don't really see much happening before your expiration though. Don't see it going down much though.

author: Adamshmadamladam
body:
I posted this as a reply to someone but think it should be put as a general message to everyone, why I am bullish on CFII:  


Great marketing, looks like an amazing product, has Google/Netflix/Hewlett Packard/some big boomer companies as clients. Projected 100% growth each year. 0 debt as of merger. Your window literally turns into the window at the beginning of Total Recall, where it dims itself and shuts off light when you want it to and can turn into a TV/tablet. Its such a sleeper its crazy imo.   


Once they start targeting people's homes, even maybe vehicles, it will change the world.
